content: Tangentially, I'll point out that Slack has a field for pronoun display and I'd love for us to do the same.

Yeah, one can add pronouns as a custom profile field today, but then you need to look at the full profile to see them. I agree we should add that, but we'll want to spend attention being thoughtful about where we display them; it's likely that displaying pronouns everywhere one's name is shown would be problematic (E.g. sidebars may not have enough width, etc.). And might need some options (Slack seems to go that route).

I wouldn't invest effort into workarounds to make it nicer nice to put pronouns into statuses which is definitely not intended for that -- better to spend that effort on the actual feature we want. (I know some organizations currently just have folks put pronouns into their name field, which is a different not always great workaround).

My suggestion would be having them visible in this part of the card, perhaps just below the name

I imagine the field would only show up at all if it is set by the user, and otherwise not occupy any vertical space. And each field would be labelled to explain what it means e.g.

pronouns: he/him
Definitely curious about other people's thoughts/takes though!

(There's also a version where we let administrators control which short custom profile fields go on your normal profile, but that has broader design consequences).

To borrow some terminology from @Yash RE, we currently have an optional non-custom field for the user's timezone. I am saying that "pronoun" could get similar treatment as "timezone".
Do we have enough consensus on this to open an issue?
I think so! I would preface it with “feature request” and link back to here.
#21214

Are folks okay with it being a plain text field? It's easier to abuse, but also lets people write whatever pronouns they want in the way they want, without having to be limited by a dropdown. And that feels important to me.

In line with ideas mentioned by Vlad Korobov , Tim Abbott and me above, I think "show this field in the profile card" should really be a flexible feature that can be associated with any profile field that's short enough that it will look reasonable. Organizations may choose to highlight users' GitHub handles, work teams, etc., etc. We can allow up to a couple of fields to be selected.

Separately, we can think about whether it's useful to have a special "Pronouns" field type. Would anything differentiate it from a regular short text custom profile field?

What are folks' thoughts on field ordering? We currently have:

  1. Name
  2. Local time
  3. Role

Perhaps it should be something like this?

  1. Name
  2. Role
  3. Custom fields/Pronouns
  4. Local time

?

Evy Kassirer said:

Are folks okay with it being a plain text field?

We already have plenty of plaintext fields that could be so abused -- and limiting options doesn't seem like the right way to push back against that abuse.

I think a plaintext field is great. I think a slightly better option would be to have a few of the more common options in a combobox, which also allows for free text entry -- but just free text is forward-compatible with that, and would go a long way.
I filed #21215 for showing custom fields in the profile card.
What is our terminology here? Why do we call the first thing you click on the profile card? Why do we even have two clicks to get to a user’s full profile info?
I don't really know what would be best to call it -- that's a good point. We need to somehow make it clear that the field will appear in the full profile no matter what.
"User popover" is our internal name for the user clicks. I think "Profile" vs. "Full profile" is our current terminology for the difference between those two components.

Alya Abbott said:

Separately, we can think about whether it's useful to have a special "Pronouns" field type. Would anything differentiate it from a regular short text custom profile field?

I do think that having the custom field for pronouns already existing, as opposed to being something a realm has the option to set up, will make it more likely to be used, which would be appreciated by users who want to add their pronouns but might not have admins who thought to set it up.
I agree with Evy here. This feels like something that should be more of a built in feature.

Pronouns are a pretty universal concept, and in the language I am most familiar with (English), it is pretty much impossible to avoid pronoun awkwardness in any kind of normal conversation if there is any ambiguity. So it would be nice if our conversation app made it as frictionless as possible.
Would the MVP for this field just be "sugar" for a short-text field, perhaps with the "show in profile" box checked by default?
I don’t know if we even need sugar here to achieve an MVP. The precedent here is timezone.
pronouns are usually more open-ended than timezone. they should probably have some form of free text, rather than just be a dropdown.
thus, I think, the suggestion for a text field with some auto-complete sugar or something
Oh I didn’t mean to suggest they should be a drop down. It should definitely be a text field, and I see no need for autocomplete.
My analogy to time zone was only about it being a built in field that users aren’t forced to specify, but which shows up in the user popup.

While pronouns are pretty universal, gendered pronouns are not. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_neutrality_in_genderless_languages

So I don't think all organizations would need such a field, whereas custom fields are more flexible.

English is a relatively genderless language, but pronouns are definitely gendered. I think the most prominent language in that wiki article is Persian? I don’t think it’s a big deal to provide pronoun support for communities that are lucky enough to converse in a mostly genderless language. We definitely want it to be an optional field for the user, but it feels unnecessary to me to have admins suppress it.

Before we get too distracted in debating questions that don't affect our product direction here, here's my thinking on the core context here:

  • We want to add support for pronouns; I think everyone agrees with that.
  • The core design question here is whether the features we're discussing for pronouns are things that one might want for another custom profile field. If so, it's likely less technical work to extend the custom profile fields feature to support the generally useful features we want a Pronouns field to have, and then have potentially some sugar on top of that to make it easy to create such a field. (In part because custom profile fields provide a lot of useful infrastructure already).
I think it is easier to solve concrete issues than abstract issues. Our profiles are already overly abstract.

Specifically, in terms of generic features I would start with:

  • We can add a generic custom profile fields feature to show up to 2 custom profile fields in the small user popovers. (Already filed as #21215)
  • We can add a generic custom profile fields feature to allow short text fields to have some easily chosen options; basically that's a hybrid of the existing Select and Short Text field types. I believe the details of this are a good discussion topic.

Those are both self-contained changes that would provide infrastructure needed for this feature. And from there, we can readily implement whatever UX we want for custom profile fields. (Including the option of having new organizations start with a Pronouns custom profile field or whatever other direction we decide we like). But my understanding of the technical side of this is that we'll want to build on top of custom profile fields for data storage and synchronization for any version of a Pronouns feature.
This feels like over engineering.

This approach will require less work to implement and to maintain and provides more value to users. I'm not sure what would be overengineering here other than Custom Profile Fields existing in the first place, and that's an important product requirement (all of our peer products have it, for good reason, since it serves as an employee directory equivalent).
I don’t agree that it’s less work to implement.
I don’t really understand the employee directory justification for custom profile fields, since in most corporate environments you could simply hyperlink to the directory page.
A lot of companies these days don't buy employee directory software; they just use their chat tool's directory for the job.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I don’t agree that it’s less work to implement.

Well, you may be right in terms of the work for the implementer. But for product design, I generally model how much work I'll spend on reviewing and integrating a feature, since that's our limited resource, and I have a pretty good simulator for what types of things end up taking more or less of my time.
We have the entire screen available to us to show the entire user profile with a single click (including custom profile fields). Are we solving the wrong problem here?
It’s already completely possible for an admin to make a pronoun field. The problem is that to get to the user profile, we make you click twice. Why?

A few reasons:

  • The small popover has a bunch of options for common interactions you might want to do with another user, like reply to a message mentioning them.
  • It's often helpful to be able to still see messages at the same time as that content / those interactions.
  • The full profile information has a bunch of lower value information that one wants to be able to access, but isn't important to access often.
  • Fullscreen modals (effectively our "overlays) that cover most/all content are a design pattern one wants to avoid for lightweight operations (like "I want to know a bit about this user and maybe mention them").
  • Our current "full profile" modal is much uglier than the "user information" popover :smile:.

I filed #21271 for a "pronouns" custom profile field type. I think this design is much better than a mandatory pronouns field. It requires a very small amount of additional work for administrators to add such a field to their organization (along with any other custom profile fields they are creating). And by keeping the field optional, we won't be making Zulip feel like an English language-centric product, and instead will be inclusive of a variety of languages and cultures.
By the way, it would be great if someone with admin privileges could add a "Pronouns" short text profile field to CZO. :)

Maybe that's too much clutter - I don't know much about what the onboarding experience for admins is right now.

Yup. I haven't seen this exactly, but somebody on twitter I think was commenting on a teacher who asked "what should I call you in class? What should I call you to your parents?" and saying they appreciated getting both questions. My guess is something similar might come up in other communities with members likely to have different pronouns in different contexts (based, eg, on how out they are).
